Literature Review:
Migraine, a debilitating neurovascular disorder, has long been associated with the meninges, the protective layers surrounding the brain and spinal cord. The meninges are richly innervated by primary afferent fibers from the trigeminal nerve, which play a pivotal role in the pathophysiology of migraine. Electrical or mechanical stimulation of these trigeminal nerve fibers, particularly those surrounding large blood vessels, can evoke headache patterns reminiscent of migraine, suggesting a direct link between meningeal mechanisms and migraine pathogenesis (Levy et al., 2007).

The trigeminal nerve's afferent fibers, which contain neuropeptides such as calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) and substance P, are crucial in mediating neurogenic inflammation within the meninges. This inflammation is characterized by vasodilation, plasma protein extravasation, and mast cell degranulation, contributing to the sensitization of meningeal nociceptors and the development of migraine pain (Moskowitz, 1993). The release of these neuropeptides from trigeminal afferents not only exacerbates inflammation but also sensitizes adjacent meningeal tissues, leading to the perception of pain in migraine sufferers.

Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) has emerged as a significant player in the migraine process, potentially acting as a conduit for signaling molecules released from the brain to the pain-sensitive meningeal tissues. This hypothesis is supported by findings that changes in CSF composition can influence meningeal nociception, suggesting a complex interplay between the brain, CSF, and meninges in migraine pathophysiology (Schain et al., 2017).

Recent studies have highlighted the importance of meningeal neuroimmune interactions in migraine. Immune cells within the meninges, such as macrophages and mast cells, can interact with trigeminal afferents to modulate pain signaling. These interactions may contribute to the chronicity of migraine and represent a novel therapeutic target (Zhang et al., 2019).

Cortical spreading depression (CSD), a wave of neuronal and glial depolarization that spreads across the cerebral cortex, has been implicated in the aura phase of migraine. CSD can activate trigeminal afferents and induce changes in meningeal blood flow, further linking meningeal mechanisms to migraine (Charles & Baca, 2013).

The sensitization of meningeal nociceptors is a critical factor in the transition from episodic to chronic migraine. Sensitization can result from repeated episodes of neurogenic inflammation, leading to increased responsiveness of trigeminal afferents to normally innocuous stimuli (Burstein et al., 2000).

Current migraine therapies, both prophylactic and abortive, target the mechanisms underlying neurogenic inflammation and sensitization. CGRP receptor antagonists and monoclonal antibodies against CGRP or its receptor have shown efficacy in migraine prevention, underscoring the importance of the CGRP pathway in migraine pathophysiology (Edvinsson et al., 2018).

Emerging concepts in migraine research, such as the role of meningeal lymphatic vessels in the clearance of inflammatory mediators, offer new insights into the disease's mechanisms and potential therapeutic avenues (Louveau et al., 2015).

In conclusion, the meninges play a central role in the pathophysiology of migraine, with trigeminal afferents, neuropeptides, and neuroimmune interactions contributing to the development and maintenance of migraine pain. Understanding these mechanisms is crucial for the development of more effective migraine therapies.
